history.content:
The course is mostly self-contained, other than some calculus knowledge about integration, differentiation, and limits. The course does not explicitly rely even on CS70 probability, since it starts at the definition of what probability and random variables are. However, the course moves quickly, so CS70 knowledge/intuition can help quite a bit.

Officially, the course is meant to build on CS70, so I think you should be fine (assuming that you allocate sufficient time to the class to study), especially given your background in math competitions.

----------

op - thanks! I have calc knowledge through bc, and I'll be taking 53 concurrently. I think i'll try it next semester, and drop it if it becomes too much. thanks for the help!

what is the prerequisite knowledge for this course? besides probability in cs 70, is it mostly self contained? I looked at notes for the course, and it stops making sense after a few lectures. I want to take it next semester, but I'm not sure if cs 70 is enough. I have a strong math background, and I've done math competitions before.
history.subject: eecs 126 difficulty
